p: Vaccinia LAVs are potent but reactogenic, and complications are very uncommon but can be serious [ 55]. They are also unsuitable for immunocompromised individuals who would be most at risk in the case of an epidemic [ 56]. In light of recent outbreaks of known and novel zoonotic poxviruses [ 57, 58, 59, 60] and the potential use of smallpox in bioterrorism [ 51], second-generation vaccines such as ACAM2000 [ 61] and CJ-50300 [ 62] have been derived from original vaccinia strains in tissue culture, and other LAVs have been made from the highly attenuated, modified vaccinia Ankara strain [ 63, 64]. Further understanding of the interaction of vaccinia LAV with the human immune system will be a major part of developing new LAVs to combat Orthpoxviruses in the future.
